info.game_comments: 2005 Ultimate Tournament of Champions Round 1, game 39.

(1, 1).clue: Group name of the Vegas entertainers seen here doing their thing in the '60s

(2, 1).clue: In the 1944 Warner Bros. cartoon "Birdy and the Beast", it was the birdy

(3, 1).clue: On June 5, 1968 a disgruntled Palestinian immigrant shot him at Los Angeles' Ambassador Hotel

(4, 1).clue: A succulent can be any plant with fleshy, thick tissues adapted to store this

(6, 1).clue: A surgeon might be tempted to remove this collection of supplementary material at the end of a book

(1, 2).clue: The Las Vegas area was a frequent venue for these post-World War II events conducted by the U.S. government

(2, 2).clue: Zoinks!  This TV cartoon dog celebrated his 35th anniversary in 2004 (that's his 245th in dog years)

(3, 2).clue: Of his horse, this general lamented, "Traveller, my only companion, I may say my only pleasure"

(4, 2).clue: The aye-aye, a primate, was once classified in this order due to its sloping incisors & incessant gnawing

(5, 2).clue: World War I flying ace Frank Luke

(6, 2).clue: Meaning artificial or fake, it can precede naif or pas

(1, 3).clue: Bugsy Siegel opened this pleasure palace seen here on the Strip in 1946, long before it became a Hilton

(2, 3).clue: Jean Vander Pyl was the voice of Rosie the Robot maid on this futuristic cartoon series

(3, 3).clue: In 1911 in recognition of his Arctic exploration, Congress made him a rear admiral

(4, 3).clue: Ants belong to the insect order Hymenoptera, which means "membrane" this

(6, 3).clue: It's the outer layer of the cerebrum largely responsible for higher nervous function

(1, 4).clue: Here's a 1950s shot of this downtown main drag named for an explorer who once visited the area

(2, 4).clue: Originally, Nickelodeon aired episodes of this wallaby's "Modern Life"

(3, 4).clue: Brahms had some unfinished business with this composer's wife Clara; he was in love with her

(4, 4).clue: Much of this cold, treeless plain in the Arctic is covered by a thick growth of lichens

(6, 4).clue: Province House in this provincial capital is Canada's oldest Parliament building

(1, 5).clue: Vegas began in 1905 when a railroad owned by this man, for whom Vegas' county is named, sold off land

(2, 5).clue: Hey, mama!  This smooth-talkin', biceps-bulgin', self-obessin' guy premiered on the Cartoon Network in '97

(3, 5).clue: This author is most famous for creating Conan, the warrior barbarian from Cimmeria

(4, 5).clue: The yucca species of this insect lays its eggs in the seed-producing organs of the yucca plant

(6, 5).clue: John Updike used this word meaning "brought back" in the title of a 1971 novel

(1, 1).clue: This disease is the most common cause of dementia & severe memory loss in people over 65

(3, 1).clue: In Len Deighton's "SS-GB", the Nazis have occupied England & sent this leader before a firing squad

(4, 1).clue: This Himalayan kingdom's Ngultrum currency features 2 dragons facing each other

(5, 1).clue: On January 6, 2004 Apple announced that more than 2 million of these had been sold since their introduction

(6, 1).clue: In the 1930s Allen True designed the one on Wyoming's license plates

(1, 2).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew holds up a piece of gross anatomy in the Body Worlds exhibit at the California Science Center.)  The arteries sub-divide into a network of aterials in these organs that filter the waste from the blood

(2, 2).clue: "A League of Their Own","Renaissance Man","Riding in Cars with Boys"

(3, 2).clue: This German field marshall turns the tide against the Allies in the novel "Fox on the Rhine"

(4, 2).clue: It's retained closer ties to Russia than any other former Soviet Republic

(5, 2).clue: Joseph Pulitzer game $2 million to this college in part to establish a school of journalism

(6, 2).clue: Downcast English schoolboys were once told to keep a stiff upper lip & jolly well do this, meaning be cheerful

(1, 3).clue: Snoring can be a sign of this disorder in which there's a temporary stopping of breathing

(3, 3).clue: In his 2004 novel "The Plot Against America", Nazi sympathizer Charles Lindbergh beats FDR in 1940

(4, 3).clue: It's surrounded on 3 sides by Malaysia

(5, 3).clue: The name of this North African capital city of 2 million comes from the Arabic "al-jaza'ir" or "the island"

(6, 3).clue: Daffy Duck's "Duck Dodgers" character is a parody of him

(1, 4).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew wanders about in a medical lab at the University of Pittsburgh.)  I'm at the University of Pittsburgh where Jonas Salk developed his polio vaccine using the controversial de-activated virus method usually called this

(2, 4).clue: "The Untouchables","Body Double","The Bonfire of the Vanities"

(3, 4).clue: The Nazis & Japanese occupy 1962 America in Philip K. Dick's novel "The Man in " this place

(4, 4).clue: It takes its name from a people of ancient Gaul & is officially a constitutional kingdom

(5, 4).clue: In 1948 more than 2 million tons of food, fuel & other supplies were airlifted into this city

(6, 4).clue: Phrase meaning to go against the established order, or a Quizno's dollar-off promotion

(1, 5).clue: Greek for "speechlessness", & often caused by a stroke, it's the loss of the ability to speak & understand words

(2, 5).clue: "Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas","Twelve Monkeys"

(3, 5).clue: In this Robert Harris book, the Nazis won WWII & JFK's dad, Joseph, is U.S. President

(4, 5).clue: Its Altiplano region was home to the great Tihuanaco empire

(5, 5).clue: From the Greek for "most recent", this epoch began about 2 million years ago & saw the 1st appearance of humans

(6, 5).clue: Containing Doylestown & Quakertown, it's home to 600,000 Pennsylvanians

(0, 0).clue: This president arranged the first film showing in the White House when he had "The Birth of a Nation" screened there
